titleStmt.title: Exceeding joyfull newes from the Earl of Bedford, Lord Generall of the Horse, that is now set forth for the defence of the Protestant religion. Declaring the happy and fortunate successe of the Ptotestant [sic] army at Siege-moore in Sommersetshire, upon the 19. day of this instant month of August, who having received a challange from the Lord Paulet, Sir Ralph Hopton, and Sir John Stowell, daring them to meet them at the said moor at the time and place appointed. Which said gentlemen upon the 19. day assembled at Siege-moor with great number of men, where Sir Francis Popham, Mr. Pine, and Mr. Stroud met them wich [sic] 6000. horse and foot, and after some parley concerning the King and Parliament, they fell to blowes, but after some 6, hours fight Sir Francis obtained the victory. The said Lord Paulet and his accomplices stood for the commission of array, and Sir Francis and the rest of the gentlemen for the ordinance of Parliament.

Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

titleStmt.title: Exceeding joyfull newes from the Earl of Bedford, Lord Generall of the Horse, that is now set forth for the defence of the Protestant religion. Declaring the happy and fortunate successe of the Ptotestant [sic] army at Siege-moore in Sommersetshire, upon the 19. day of this instant month of August, who having received a challange from the Lord Paulet, Sir Ralph Hopton, and Sir John Stowell, daring them to meet them at the said moor at the time and place appointed. Which said gentlemen upon the 19. day assembled at Siege-moor with great number of men, where Sir Francis Popham, Mr. Pine, and Mr. Stroud met them wich [sic] 6000. horse and foot, and after some parley concerning the King and Parliament, they fell to blowes, but after some 6, hours fight Sir Francis obtained the victory. projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Exceeding Joyfull NEWES FROM The Earl of Bedford, Lord Generall of the Hor≈øe, that is now ≈øet forth for the Defence of the Prote≈øtant RELIGION.

Declaring the happy and fortunate Succe≈ø≈øe of the Prote≈øtant Army at Siege-Moore in Sommer≈øet-≈øhire, upon the 19. day of this in≈øtant month of Augu≈øt, who having received a Challenge from the Lord Paulet, Sir Ralph Hopton, and Sir John Stowell, daring them to meet them at the ≈øaid Moor at the time and place appointed.

Which ≈øaid Gentlemen upon the 19. day a≈ø≈øembled at Siege-Moor with a great number of men, where Sir Francis Popham, Mr. Pine, and Mr. Str ‚Ä¢ nd met them with 6000. Hor≈øe and Foot and after ≈øome parley concerning the King and parliament, they fell to blowes, but after ≈øome 6, hours fight. Sir Francis obtained the Victory.
The ≈øaid Lord Paulet and his Accomplices ≈øtood for the Commi≈ø≈øion of Array, and Sir Francis and the re≈øt of the Gentlemen for the Ordinance of Parliament.
London Printed, for Thomas Berriman; dwelling in Great St. Bartholomews. Angu≈øt 23. 1642.

div.head: Exceeding Joyfull NEVVS FROM FROM Sommer≈øet-≈øhire.
div.p: ON the 16. day of Augu≈øt, there was a meeting of divers Gentlemen at Sir Iohn Stowell his hou≈øe at Ham, where after much di≈øcour≈øe among≈øt them ≈øelves, they contrived away how they might put the Commi≈ø≈øion of Array in execution, and ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe all tho≈øe that ≈øhould oppo≈øe them therin, Sir Ralph Hopton replyed, that it were an ca≈øie thing to be done.

list.item:
Fir≈øt, con≈øidering my Lord Paul ‚Ä¢ ts powerfulne≈ø≈øe in the Ea≈øt part of the ≈øhire, and what mean Forces there abouts can ari≈øe to hinder his Proceedings therin, the rather for his part in regard
of Ma≈øter Digbies a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of Hor≈øe and Foot.
II. For his own part he ≈øaid he hath gotten the good will of the County therabouts his quarter, notwith≈øtanding Mr. Alexander Popham, or Sir Iohn Horner, do they what they can.

III. For Iihn Stowel it was ≈øaid his oppo≈øers were many, namely, Sir Francis Popham, Mr. Pine M. Coles, M. Nevvton, and divers others; yet they thought his part of the County were as ea≈øie to be brought under ≈øubjection, as any of them, all the rather, becau≈øe he hath great Lord≈øhips and Mannors about the We≈øt part of the ≈øhire, and that his Tenants, mo≈øt of them holdeth their Lands by Rack-rent; ≈øo that if they would not obey his command, he might out with them.

IV. And la≈øtly, for Sir Francis Dorington, Sir Ferdinando Gorge, and Mr. Smith, they ≈øaid that they thought the Inhabitants of the City of Bri≈øtoll, and Bath wovld help and a≈ø≈øi≈øt them, notwith≈øtanding Mr. Hollis or Mr. Stroud; after which agreement they concluded and prefixed a day, place, and hour, of meeting, which was the following, being ihe 18. of Augu≈øt.

div.p: And that every one of the≈øe Gentlemen ‚Ä¢ efore-mentioned, ≈øhould make what expedition they could in Rai≈øing each feverall mans quarters, and to force their Neighbors and Tenants ‚Ä¢ o be well armed with powder and ≈øhot, and the Pikes to be in the Arrear of the Mu≈øquetiers, and the Hor≈øe to be in Arrear of all the Pikes, which was about the number of five thou≈øand ≈øouldiers, all o meet at a place called Siege-more, upon the Eleventh of Augu≈øt, about o ‚Ä¢ e of the clock, at the Ea≈øt part of ≈øaid Moore, neere adjoyning to Donnington and Sommerton.

Sir Francis Popham and his Son Mr. Pine, Mr Stroud, and the re≈øt having had notice ≈øent them by the≈øe Cavaleers, that at ≈øuch a day, place, and houre, they would put the Commi≈ø≈øion of Array in execution, in defiance of them all, that if any offered to oppo≈øe them in the execution thereof, let them be a≈ø≈øured ehey ≈øhall ≈øuffer for their attempt, though they hazzard their Lives and Fortunes therein.

The ≈øaid Sir Francis with the re≈øt of the Gent ‚Ä¢ y in the County, fearing no threatnings, cau≈øed the drums to beat up, charging the Trained Bands to be in readine≈ø≈øe, and every Captain of the train Bands to lead his Company to the ≈øaid Moore at the day appointed, and about 6000 met at the place and hour, the Cavaleers them≈øelves dur≈øt not venture neer their ≈øoldiers, for feare of Treacherie by their own Companies.

For there was not a word of Command obeyed by the Cavaleers, upon which they all rid their wayes, and took their commanding ≈øervants and Sir Iohn Stowell dangerou≈øly ≈øhot in the breech, yet he got away before any could over take him, and the Country being thus met together on both ≈øides, the one part to put the Commi≈øsion of Array in execution the other the Militia, con≈øented all ingenerall to put the Militia in execution where they exerci≈øed for three hours ≈øpace, only three Captains in the Lord Paulets Regiment, and two Captains under M. Smith his Regiment, refu≈øed to put their ≈øouldiers in ranck or file, or to exerci≈øe them.
Whereupon they were apprehended and carried to pri≈øon, till Order from the Parliament.

The Country ≈øince the la≈øt four Troope of Hor≈øe, ≈øent by the Earl of Bedford, who is Lord Lieutenant of the ≈øhire, hath kept the Countrey in peace and quietne≈ø≈øe, for they are quartered within a mile of each Gentlemans habitation or man≈øion hou≈øe.

The City of Wells hath been much rifled and racked, and the Cavaleers have poled and pinched the poor of the City, and hath made ≈øuch an ob≈øtacle of the town, that it is not 10000. l. will make ≈øatisfaction.

The Town Goal are full of the meaner ≈øort of people, and the chiefe Agents was willfully let gone; after which there was Order taken for by the Committee and Ju≈øtices, having therefore
maturely and judiciou≈øly con≈øidered, that the chief ≈øpring of all our mi≈øeries de≈øcends from tho≈øe corrupt Fountains, have thought it meete and expedient that there ≈øhould a troop of hor≈øe daily at the Lord Paulet his hou≈øe, for the more ≈øecurity of the peace of the ≈øhire, and ≈øo about every of the ≈øaid Gentlemens hou≈øes a Troope of hor≈øe for their apprehending, that therby the Countymay be clean≈øed rom ≈øuch corrupt members that contaminate the ≈øanctity of the Lowes in an ob≈øtinate exulcecration: but it is to be feared they are gone out of the ≈øhire el≈øe they would have bin taken ere this, in regard of their dayly ≈øearches made about their hou≈øes, and in mo≈øt parts of the ≈øhire.

On Friday after the mu≈øtering of the trayned Bands, there was a privie ≈øear ‚Ä¢ h at one Mi≈øtris Ward her hou≈øe a widdow woman, and a great Recu≈øant for M. Smith neere Bridgewater, and at Mr. Harvies hou≈øe an Alderman ≈øometime of Baidgewater, for Sir Iohn Stowell, but no per≈øon found therein, but there was Ammunition and Armour found in widdow Ward her hou≈øe, for above 100. ≈øouldiers.

A little boy ≈øeeing the Rifling of the Hou≈øe, ≈øaid that his Father had a great company of ≈øuch Ouns too; hereupon the Searchers went with the Child, and fearched all that Village of Ware, and took from the widdow Ward and neere upon 400. Arms, and many ≈øorts of Engines, the Tenants
were all committed to ≈øafe cu≈øtody: and this is all for the pre≈øent I can certifie you with all, till the next Po≈øt.

The Captains of the City of London were appointed to attend the Committee for Defence of the Kingdom, to con≈øider of fit and convenient places for the making of Out-works for the Defence and ≈øafety of the City of London, and the Suburbs thereof.
